user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskExit:
```c
void OS_TaskExit()
{
    osal_id_t         task_id;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    task_id = OS_TaskGetId_Impl();
    if (OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, task_id, &token) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_TaskDetach_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(OS_SUCCESS, &token);
    }

    /* call the implementation */
    OS_TaskExit_Impl();

    /* Impl function never returns */
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, task_id, &token) == OS_SUCCESS)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The local variable ‘token’ is passed by address to OS_ObjectIdGetById as an output parameter and is intended to be modified by that function, so the pointer must not be const. Rule 8.13 would be violated only if the pointed-to object could be treated as const (i.e. the function does not modify it) but the API/prototype omits the const qualifier — there is no evidence of that here.
